spec.name: 16th November Square
spec.description: Place du 16 Novembre is a historic square in Casablanca, named after November 16, 1955, the day King Mohammed V returned from exile. It is one of the best spots to admire iconic Casablanca architecture, surrounded by remarkable early 20th-century buildings such as the Baille, Bendahan, and Tazi buildings.

timeline.title: Creation of the square
timeline.description: The square was laid out in the late 1920s and early 1930s after the surrounding buildings were completed. It was first named Place des 5 Parties du Monde and later renamed Place Edmond Doutté.

timeline.title: Return of the Sultan from Exile
timeline.description: Sultan Sidi Mohammed Ben Youssef and the royal family returned to Morocco after two years of forced exile, a historic event commemorated by Place du 16 Novembre.

timeline.title: Design of Prince Moulay Abdellah Pedestrian Street
timeline.description: Architect Jean-François Zevaco designed the pedestrian Prince Moulay Abdellah Street during the 1970s.

timeline.title: Creation of the 'Source of Life' Sculpture
timeline.description: Artist Abdelhak Sijelmassi created the ceramic sculpture 'Source de Vie,' accompanied by a fountain at Place du 16 Novembre.

timeline.title: First Restoration of the Fountain
timeline.description: The fountain surrounding the 'Source de Vie' sculpture underwent its first restoration.

timeline.title: Second Restoration of the Fountain
timeline.description: A second restoration was carried out to preserve the 'Source de Vie' sculpture and its fountain.
